stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on Course 11, focusing on a scene where Bowser's minions are on strike. Activities included performance optimization for N64 hardware, generating and refining protestor dialogue using AI and team input, designing the interior of Bowser's office, and meticulously planning a multi-stage cinematic trigger for the level's boss fight. The stream also featured animation reviews and rigging feedback with Zeina.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has been actively optimizing Course 11 for N64 hardware, achieving a target of 25-29 FPS in the level's most demanding areas, which he considers acceptable.
development_findings.quote: 25 for the worst part of the level, in a level like this, I'm fine with that.

development_findings.summary: A custom pop-in hiding technique was implemented where enemies smoothly animate out of the ground upon entering the render distance, masking their sudden appearance.
development_findings.quote: You see how he like smoothly scaled, and now when I come close, he comes back out of the ground.

development_findings.summary: A design choice was made to not give Thwomps hats, based on the in-world logic that Bowser would not waste resources on an already invulnerable minion.
development_findings.quote: The Thwomps are invulnerable, they don't need hats. You think Bowser would spend money on a hat on an enemy that's already invulnerable? Yes, because he's that dumb. No!

development_findings.summary: Kaze used ChatGPT as a tool for brainstorming dialogue for the protesting minions, leveraging it for initial ideas and puns which were then refined or replaced.
development_findings.quote: I am making a level where Bowser's minions are striking against Bowser... Give me five short dialogues that the worker wants to say.

development_findings.summary: A detailed multi-part sequence was designed to trigger the Act 3 boss fight. The player will overhear an enraged Bowser, exit his office to find the protesting minions have vanished and the music has stopped, creating tension before an ambush.
development_findings.quote: You enter there, and he's gonna be really, really upset... And then you come back out... and the plaza's empty... and the music has gone quiet.

development_findings.summary: A secret Yoshi coin is planned for inside Bowser's Tower, accessible by finding a way to escape the elevator shaft during its ascent and navigating a hidden area.
A unique visual gag was successfully implemented where a flattened Goomba's dialogue box is also squished vertically, requiring a custom coding solution.
development_findings.quote: Hey, we get the flat text, alright, it works.

development_findings.summary: Multiplayer is a planned future feature, though it is contingent on implementing quaternion animations first and is expected to have significant performance costs.
development_findings.quote: I'm planning to add multiplayer after we have Quaternion animations. Unfortunately, I don't know how well it's going to run. I think the lowest it will run is like 20 FPS.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes replayability in his games should come from player skill improvement and discovering shortcuts, rather than unlockable content or a New Game+ mode.
context_findings.quote: You get better at Mario, you find new shortcuts that have replayability.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong creative principle against including out-of-place memes, aiming to maintain a consistent tone and world in the project.
context_findings.quote: I think just adding random memes to your hacks is just cringe. Unless it's specifically a meme hack, you should not do it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering selling physical merchandise like game boxes, manuals, and OST cartridges but is aware of the legal complexities, such as trademarks on 'Yoshi' and the rights to musical samples, and plans to consult a lawyer.
context_findings.quote: I would have to look into whether it's legal to, like, sell the OST if it has a few samples that are also used in Mario 64... I would definitely ask a lawyer beforehand.

context_findings.summary: Kaze floated a future project idea: a large-scale, community-driven Ocarina of Time ROM hack managed professionally with roles, GitHub, and QA, intended as a collaborative learning experience.
context_findings.quote: I was thinking we should develop like an Ocarina of Time hack. But instead of developing it like normally, we'll do it like a professional game studio... I think it'd be like a cool experience for everyone involved.

context_findings.summary: When deciding on dialogue, Kaze weighs the maturity of puns, concluding that a wordplay like 'pain in the asphalt' is acceptable as it would likely be interpreted literally by younger players.
context_findings.quote: I don't think it's mature. A little kid's gonna look at that and be like, oh, haha, asphalt. That's a brick thing.

biobak.summary: Biobak offered to work on the 3D model and texture for the 'oil block' enemy after Kaze solicited criticism on his initial design.
biobak.quote: He says he has an idea.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided several clever, pun-based dialogue lines for the protesting Koopas, which Kaze praised as being better than the AI-generated suggestions.
biobak.quote: They're gonna replace all the writers with Biobak. They're all gonna be jobless.

badub.summary: No direct contributions from Badub were discussed during the stream, though Kaze did play and enjoy music from the game's OST, including tracks inspired by Mario Strikers.

zeina.summary: Zeina provided crucial feedback on the Wiggler's animation rig, pointing out that the root bone's placement on the chest made animation difficult, prompting Kaze to reposition it.
zeina.quote: Why do you not name your bones boy?

zeina.summary: Zeina presented a work-in-progress walk cycle for Wiggler, and Kaze provided specific feedback on its timing and motion.
zeina.quote: It looks like he's going through mud, because the part backwards is so much slower than the part forwards.

zeina.summary: Kaze and Zeina had a playful interaction about the dialogue for a flattened Goomba, workshopping a line about his wife leaving him into a less cruel, funnier version.
zeina.quote: I got flat into a pancake, my wife's going to leave me. That is cruel... Imagine the face of my wife when I slide under the front door tonight. Yes, that's the perfect one.

zeina.summary: At the end of the stream, Zeina provided several new animations for a Goomba character, including a protest hop and a fall. Kaze implemented them and decided the 'fall flat' animation was funnier on its own.

key_stories.title: The Writers' Room: Man vs. Machine
key_stories.summary: To populate a protest scene with dialogue, Kaze used ChatGPT as a starting point but found its output limited. The final, high-quality script was a hybrid of refined AI ideas and superior, context-aware puns contributed by team member Biobak.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed to write a large amount of witty, in-character dialogue for a scene where Bowser's minions are protesting poor working conditions.
key_stories.process: Kaze first used ChatGPT to generate a variety of dialogue ideas. He sifted through them, keeping the good concepts like 'crushing' puns. When the AI's ideas ran dry, Biobak contributed several more effective lines, leading Kaze to praise his natural creativity over the AI's.
key_stories.outcome: A full set of dialogue was created, blending the best AI-generated puns with superior, human-written lines from Biobak, resulting in a scene with a strong comedic identity.
key_stories.key_quote: This environment is crushing, and believe me, I know a thing or two about crushing.

key_stories.title: The Squished Goomba and His Squished Dialogue
key_stories.summary: To enhance the humor of a flattened Goomba, Kaze decided to make its dialogue box squished as well. He successfully implemented this custom visual effect through coding and refined it to maximize the comedic impact.
key_stories.challenge: A planned scene featured a Goomba flattened by Mario, but the team wanted to make the gag more impactful than just having a flat character model.
key_stories.process: Kaze came up with the idea to squish the dialogue box to match the flattened Goomba. He then implemented it in code, using a previously unused field in the dialogue data structure to pass a special flag. After successfully implementing the effect, he fine-tuned the degree of 'flatness' for comedic timing and readability.
key_stories.outcome: A unique and memorable gag was created where not only the Goomba is flat, but his dialogue box is also squished vertically. The flatness was tuned to be funny yet readable.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine the face of my wife when I slide under the front door tonight.

key_stories.title: Building the Boss Fight Ambush
key_stories.summary: Instead of a simple trigger, Kaze designed a multi-stage cinematic sequence to initiate a boss fight. The player's actions lead to a dramatic shift in the level's environment and mood, creating a sense of dread and surprise right before the ambush.
key_stories.challenge: How to trigger the level's third boss fight in a way that feels dynamic and narrative-driven, rather than having the player simply walk into an arena.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed with his chat, rejecting simple triggers. He devised a sequence: 1. Player enters Bowser's office. 2. Player overhears Bowser's tantrum about the strike. 3. Player leaves the office to find the protest plaza is now empty and the music has stopped. 4. Upon walking into the empty space, a 'strike breaker' boss ambushes the player.
key_stories.outcome: A complete, multi-step plan for a cinematic boss encounter was designed. It builds suspense by creating a drastic change in the level's atmosphere right before the fight begins.
key_stories.key_quote: As soon as you leave Bowser's tower, everyone is gone and the music has gone quiet... As soon as you walk up... the black comes out and he just eats you.
